Award.AbstractNarration: This project will use a combination of experiment and theory to test the hypothesis that mechanical forces generated by the cytoskeleton are important for efficient immune response during T cell activation. Forces generated by T cells during signaling activation will be measured and correlated with intracellular dynamics of cytoskeletal proteins and receptor clusters as well as signaling. Computer simulations of the feedback between signaling and force generation will be developed to compare with experimental results on molecular perturbations that interrupt the mechanochemical feedback. This research will provide fundamental insights into the role of physical forces in the biochemical signaling function of lymphocytes. The research project will enhance the understanding of biological systems using experimental and theoretical tools from Physics and Cell Biology. In particular, gaining deeper insights into the way immune cells are activated may facilitate future biomedical advances. A course titled Dynamics of Cells will be developed in which concepts from topics, such as statistical and continuum mechanics, will be used to explain biological processes. A laboratory component will introduce students to basic biophysics techniques and cell biology experiments. Students from disadvantaged socio-economic backgrounds, as well as high school students, especially females from the area high schools, will be encouraged to participate in research. Software developed as part of this research to model actin dynamics and mechanical signaling will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we examined how cells of the immune system respond to their environment. T cells are an essential component of the adaptive immune response. These cells recognize foreign molecules (antigens) that belong to infectious agents, develop an appropriate response, and rapidly recall this action on subsequent re-exposure. In order to do so, T cells have special proteins on their surface (T cell receptor), which can bind to specific protein fragments on other specialized immune cells. The binding of TCR with these peptides leads to activation of biochemical signaling pathways in the T cell and ultimately to transcription, cell fate determination and the immune response. Despite extensive study, the precise mechanism of this process remains unclear. Understanding this process has implications for developing better therapies for cancer. In this project, we examined the hypothesis that T cells can exert forces on the TCR as it binds to antigen, which is critical for efficient T cell activation, using a combination of advanced microscopy, image analysis and computational modeling.

Our first outcome was the development of microscopy methods and quantitative analysis tools that allowed us to track cell shapes and the dynamics of cellular polymers (the actin cytoskeleton) that is the primary force-generating element in cells. These techniques demonstrated that as the cell encounters antigen, the actin cytoskeleton is dynamically organized into traveling waves that depend on biochemical signaling initiated by the TCR. We further showed the importance of actin regulatory proteins in the establishment of these actin waves. Since these waves may be directly responsible for exerting a force on the TCR-antigen bond, we developed a sensitive assay to measure forces exerted by cells during this initial step of the immune response. We found that T lymphocytes generate weak forces (several nanoNewton), which are primarily generated by the assembly/disassembly dynamics of actin filaments. While myosin motors are important in the early stage of force generation, they are dispensable for the long-term maintenance of forces. Remarkably, the microtubule cytoskeleton, a second network of biopolymers and motor proteins in cells, also affects the cellular forces, acting through a Rho kinase pathway.

Another major outcome of this study was the finding that T cells are sensitive to the stiffness of the contacting surface – they are more dynamic and exert larger forces on substrates with increased stiffness. Further, T cell signaling is sensitive to the stiffness of the activating surface. This finding generalizes recent studies showing that the mechanical environment of cells and tissues plays a critical role in regulating many biological processes, including development and cancer.

In order to obtain a more formal understanding of the contributions of actin assembly, disassembly and network organization to force generation, we developed a highly advanced computational model for simulating cytoskeletal dynamics at single molecule resolution, in three dimensions. The key novelty of our approach is to treat chemical reactions, passive and active transports, and mechanics as equally important, in particular, taking into account complex nonlinear feedbacks between chemical and mechanical processes. To investigate the coupling between actin retrograde flows and the motions of receptor microclusters, we developed a two-region model, where the cytoskeleton is simulated in 3D within one zone, as described above, while the biochemical events denoting TCR binding and signaling are modeled in a separate slab. The two regions are mechanically coupled, allowing cytoskeletal dynamics to modulate TCR motion. Our simulations showed an interesting interplay between cytoskeletal and microcluster dynamics.
